bug.short_desc: Dynamic stylesheets are not always recognised by Chrome

long_desc.thetext:
Dynamical stylesheets such as those added by qx.bom.Stylesheet.createElement sometimes do not take effect in Chrome.
In my test case, I had a full width table using default cell renderers and the cells would not appear; this was because the cells have styling applied by creating a stylesheet and adding the "qooxdoo-table-cell" class, but the class was being ignored.
Using the Chrome Debugging tools, I could open the Elements tree to find the cell's DIV; if I click on the DIV (in the Elements pane) the cells redraw themselves correctly. If I do not click on the DIV but hover over it, a rectangle appears over the webpage showing where the DIV is...and it's below the table, well out of position.
Running this code in the javascript console also fixed the problem:
var sheet = qx.bom.Stylesheet.createElement(".stuff { font-weight: inherit; } "); qx.bom.Stylesheet.addRule(sheet, ".more-stuff", "font-weight: inherit;");
The key thing in this fix is that q.b.Stylesheet.addRule uses insertRule and *that* causes the stylesheet to be reevaluated. q.b.Stylesheet.createElement on its own does not work because it only sets the style tag's cssText property.
It's difficult to provide a reproducable test case for this because it's so hard to reproduce - the two test cases I had would not occur if that section of my app was removed into a separate, standalone application but it appeared to be connected to adding a table during the appear event of a tab view page.
There is however an easy fix for this: in qx.bom.Stylesheet.createElement, for webkit browsers only, call insertRule to create a dummy rule after adding the style tag to the document head.
This problem occurs on Chrome 18 & Safari on OSX 10.7 and Chrome 18 on XP 32bit.
Pull request to follow.
